results.title: Annelids (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Bruce J. Russell, Modern Learning Aids and Biomedia Associates
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Inhabitants of the Planet Earth”.
A small anaesthetised earthworm is shown dissected, featuring the pumping heart. Shows peristaltic contractions which mix the food and send it along the intestinal tract. Undigested “castings” are expelled and their importance in soil ecology is discussed.

results.title: Annelid worms
results.brief_description: The following are studied: land earthworms, freshwater and saltwater aquatic worms; medicinal and pond leeches; numerous marine polchaet worms; and the most primitive type of annelid larva is illustrated by a study of the trochophore larva. No other credits available.

results.title: Anne of Cleves
results.creator_credit: John Glenister, Mark Shivas, Ronald Travers and BBC
results.brief_description:
Episode number 4 of Series “The Six wives of Henry VIII”.
The story of Henry VIII’s marriage to the rawboned Anne of Cleves is the story of an alliance between England and Germany, a pact between nations not persons, a political celebration without passionate consummation. But while the annulment of that marriage amounts to a corresponding escape from political dilemmas, it also means the parting of two close friends. Stars Keith Michell as Henry VIII.

results.title: Anne Devlin
results.creator_credit: Aeon Films, Bord Scannan na Heireann, Irish Film Board, Arts Council of Great Britain, Pat Murphy and Tom Hayes
results.brief_description: From farmer’s daughter to political prisoner, Anne Devlin has remained on the periphery of formal history - hers is a history of kitchen and children, fetching and carrying, the quiet heroism of a woman who recovers and buries the dead, who withstands protracted torture. She speaks through the ‘lost’ diaries she kept while in prison. This is the second feature of Irishwoman Pat Murphy and the first all-Irish feature. Cast includes Brid Brennan and Bosco Hogan.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Aeon Films, Bord Scannan na Heireann, Irish Film Board, Arts Council of Great Britain, Pat Murphy and Tom Hayes

results.title: Anna: from 6 to 18 [Widescreen] [NTSC]
results.creator_credit: Studio Trite (Russia), Camera One (France), Nikita Mikhalkov and Michel Seydoux
results.brief_description: This captivating documentary by award winning Russian director Nikita Mikhalkov (Dark eyes, Burnt by the sun) was filmed over a period of 13 years (from 1980-1993) in clandestine conditions due to the censorius and restrictive regulations imposed by the then Soviet leader, Brezhnev. Mikhalkov’s project involved his six year-old daughter Anna, and five simple questions which were to be answered by Anna, once a year, until she reached the age of eighteen. The questions were: What scares you the most? What do you want more than anything? What do you expect from life? What do you love the most? What do you hate the most? Anna at six is delightful with her warm smile and her typically childish answers but as the years progress it is evident how Anna’s life is being shaped by the impending collapse of totalitarianism and the Soviet Union and the eventual arrival of democracy following Gorbachev’s perestroika. Mikhalkov juxtaposes his annual interviews with his daughter against a spectacular montage of historical archival footage and never-before-seen newsreels depicting the Soviet regime from the days of Brezhnev through to Yeltsin. Anna’s part in the documentary is comparatively small when measured against the wealth of historical images and personal commentary by Mikhalkov but it is the central theme to the film and provides a unique insight into the emotions and thoughts of a young Soviet girl as she grows alongside a country that is going through tremendous political, philosophical and economical upheaval. In turn, Mikhalkov also puts forward his own personal thoughts and philosophies about the old Soviet empire and the new “westernised” state of Russia, reminiscing of his own days of family and childhood. An interesting concept, almost epic in its historical coverage, intercut with moments of poetic images of the Russian rural landscape and Mikhalkov’s family home. The hint of perhaps a sequel when at the end of the documentary Mikhalkov turns to his younger daughter Nadia (aged six) and proceeds to ask her the same questions. (Award: Best Documentary Feature, Hamptons International Film Festival 1996) In Russian with English subtitles.

results.title: Anna Who?
results.creator_credit: South Australian College of Advanced Education and Pip Karmel
results.brief_description: A film which dispels the myth that Anorexia Nervosa is a slimmers disease affecting only figure conscious women. Five young people (four women and one man) talk frankly about their experience of Anorexia and Bulimia, the factors in the cause and progress of the disease, and the road to recovery.

results.title: Anna Karenina. Parts 1 & 2
results.creator_credit: Donald Wilson, BBC Enterprises and Basil Coleman
results.brief_description: Anna Karenina after being married for ten years and moving in the highest aristocratic and political circles finds herself in a failing marriage. Believing herself to be vulnerable to temptation, she meets a man who is able to awaken a love that will prove tragic and fatal. Shot in Budapest, Hungary and England this BBC dramatisation brings to life Leo Tolstoy’s classic novel. Stars Nicola Pagett and Stuart Wilson.

results.title: Anna [Italian version]
results.brief_description: Anna is the story of a young mother and her mentally handicapped son, Tom. The film traces the path followed by Anna in overcoming her distrust of professional health workers and outsiders. We follow Anna as she searches with increasing confidence, for the extra help that she is told is available to herself and young son Tom.
